question_text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of pain in her right knee. The pain is worse at the end of the day and when she walks. She says that it has become difficult for her to walk up the flight of stairs to reach her apartment. She has hypertension. Her sister has rheumatoid arthritis. She drinks two to three beers daily. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and a multivitamin. She appears anxious. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 92 kg (202 lb); BMI is 36 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 135/83 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The right knee is not tender or erythematous; range of motion is limited. Crepitus is heard on flexion and extension of the knee. Her hemoglobin concentration is 12.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,000/mm^3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 16 mm/h. An x-ray of the right knee is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
content_preview: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of pain in her right knee. The pain is worse at the end of the day and when she walks. She says that it has become difficult for her to walk up the flight of stairs to reach her apartment. She has hypertension. Her sister has rheumatoid arthritis. She drinks two to three beers daily. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and a multivitamin. She appears anxious. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 92 kg (202 lb); BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 135/83 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The right knee is not tender or erythematous; range of motion is limited. Crepitus is heard on flexion and extension of the knee. Her hemoglobin concentration is 12.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,000/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 16 mm/h. An x-ray of the right knee is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
hint: Knee pain that is worse at the end of the day, crepitus, and limited range of motion in a patient with obesity, combined with osteophytes, subchondral sclerosis, and joint space narrowing on x-ray, indicate osteoarthritis of the knee.
learning_objective: Recognize osteoarthritis of the knee, and choose the most appropriate initial management in an overweight patient.

answers.explanation_why: Intraarticular glucocorticoid injections may be administered in patients with severe osteoarthritis to provide short-term pain relief. However, glucocorticoid injections are only indicated if active joint inflammation is present or if nonpharmacological and first-line pharmacological therapy (NSAIDs) do not provide sufficient relief to overcome functional impairment.

A weight loss program is one of the most important general measures to relieve symptoms in patients with osteoarthritis who are overweight or obese. Osteoarthritis is the most common joint disorder in the US. Its incidence increases with age and it commonly affects women over the age of 50 years. The knees are the most commonly affected joints, followed by the hands and hips. Because there are only a few modifiable risk factors in patients with osteoarthritis, including obesity and excessive joint loading or overuse, causal treatment is limited and weight loss is the most effective step in management at this time.

If lifestyle changes (moderate exercise, weight loss) and physical therapy do not improve symptoms or patients have persistent pain, pharmacological treatment may be required. First-line pharmacological treatment consists of NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen).

answers.content: Arthrocentesis of the right knee joint
answers.explanation_why: Arthrocentesis is commonly performed in patients with joint effusions to evaluate synovial fluid for crystals (e.g., in crystal-induced arthropathies like gout), leukocytes, and gram-staining (e.g., presence of bacteria in septic arthritis). Patients with both septic arthritis and crystal-induced arthropathies can present with arthralgias and a limited range of motion. However, septic arthritis is usually associated with systemic symptoms (e.g., fever), while both conditions are typically associated with an acute onset, significant swelling, and erythema of the joint. The patient has none of these features.

Total joint replacement (endoprosthesis) is the treatment of choice in patients with osteoarthritis if conservative and interventional measures fail. But this patient has not received any treatment yet, meaning total joint replacement is not indicated at this time.

Methotrexate is the first-line treatment for moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis (RA). RA typically manifests with joint pain, as in this patient. She might also have a genetic predisposition given her sister's history. However, RA most commonly affects small finger joints, and patients present with symmetrical swelling of the joints and morning stiffness that typically improves with activity. This patient has none of these symptoms, so RA is very unlikely.

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the preferred method to evaluate soft tissue and cartilage of the knee. MRI can show precisely what damage has been done to the soft tissue within the knee (e.g., meniscus rupture, cruciate ligament injury). MRI is not indicated in the majority of patients with osteoarthritis unless an underlying pathology such as meniscus rupture is suspected.

images.title: Lateral compartment osteoarthritis of the knee
images.description: X-ray right knee (AP view)Marked lateral compartment narrowing (indicated by white lines and arrows) is accompanied by subchondral sclerosis (green overlay) and osteophyte formation (red overlay). Tibial spine osteophytes (example indicated by yellow overlay) are also visible.

question_text: A 2-week old newborn is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination after the initial newborn examination showed asymmetry of the legs. She was born at term to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. Pregnancy was complicated by a breech presentation for which she underwent an emergency lower segment transverse cesarean section. The newborn's head circumference is 35 cm (13.7 in). She is at the 60th percentile for length and 75th percentile for weight. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The spine is normal. Abduction of the right hip after cupping the pelvis and flexing the right hip and knee causes a palpable clunk. The feet have no deformities. Ultrasonography of the hip determines the angle between lines along the bone acetabulum and the ilium is 50°. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 2-week old newborn is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination after the initial newborn examination showed asymmetry of the legs. She was born at term to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. Pregnancy was complicated by a breech presentation for which she underwent an emergency lower segment transverse cesarean section. The newborn's head circumference is 35 cm (13.7 in). She is at the 60th percentile for length and 75th percentile for weight. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The spine is normal. Abduction of the right hip after cupping the pelvis and flexing the right hip and knee causes a palpable clunk. The feet have no deformities. Ultrasonography of the hip determines the angle between lines along the bone acetabulum and the ilium is 50°. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This newborn has a positive Ortolani sign (the clunk heard and felt on abducting her flexed hip), which suggests developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). The sex of the child (female) and a breech presentation are risk factors for DDH. An alpha angle (angle between lines along the bone acetabulum and the ilium) of less than 60° on ultrasound also indicates DDH.
learning_objective: Recognize developmental dysplasia of the hip, and choose the most appropriate initial management for a newborn.

answers.content: Reassure the mother and schedule follow-up appointment in 4 weeks
answers.explanation_why: In most infants, mild hip instability (e.g., the femoral head is subluxable) resolves spontaneously within the first 6–8 weeks of life, as growth of the femoral head and acetabulum reduces hip laxity. If mild hip instability is detected at neonatal screening, close observation, and repeat examination after 2–6 weeks are appropriate. However, in infants with clinical evidence of hip instability (e.g., the femoral head is dislocatable) and abnormal ultrasound findings, DDH is unlikely to resolve without treatment. These infants are at high risk of developing a functional disability and accelerated osteoarthritis in the course of their lives. Expectant management would therefore not be appropriate.

answers.content: Immobilize the hips with a spica cast
answers.explanation_why: In the case of DDH, a hip spica cast is indicated only after an open or closed reduction of the femoral head or following a pelvic or femoral osteotomy. Since none of these procedures were performed in this infant, a hip spica cast would not be appropriate.

answers.content: Obtain an x-ray of the right hip
answers.explanation_why: An x-ray of the hip is not useful for assessing the hip joint at birth because the head of the femur is unossified for the first 4 months and cartilaginous structures do not appear on an x-ray. A hip x-ray would be appropriate (instead of an ultrasound) if the child were older than 4 months.

answers.content: Perform closed reduction of the right hip
answers.explanation_why: The clunk heard during the Ortolani maneuver (abduction of a flexed hip) indicates reduction of the dislocated hip. Therefore, further maneuvers to reduce the hip are not needed. In infants with DDH older than 6 months, contractures develop around the hip joint and make hip abduction difficult. Closed reduction of the hip joint under general anesthesia would be indicated in such a scenario.

A harness that keeps the hips abducted to 50° and flexed to 90–100° to achieve concentric reduction of the femoral head is the treatment of choice for DDH in infants who are less than 6 months old. The harness should be worn for at least 23 hours/day for 6–8 weeks. The type of abduction harness (rigid vs. nonrigid harness) used varies by region and institutional protocols.

Nonrigid harnesses (e.g., the Pavlik harness) are the most commonly used orthotic among patients with DDH, although recent evidence suggests rigid harnesses (e.g., von Rosen harness) are associated with better outcomes.

answers.content: Perform open reduction of the right hip
answers.explanation_why: Open reduction of the dislocated femoral head is the treatment of choice for DDH in patients 12–18 months of age. In individuals > 18 months of age, pelvic and/or femoral osteotomy may also be performed. This patient is 2 weeks old and therefore requires a different step in management.

question_text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing pain in her right hip for 2 months. The pain is intermittent, presenting at the lateral side of the hip and radiating towards the thigh. It is aggravated while climbing stairs or lying on the right side. Two weeks ago, the patient was treated with a course of oral prednisone for exacerbation of asthma. Her current medications include formoterol-budesonide and albuterol inhalers. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows tenderness to palpation over the upper lateral part of the right thigh. There is no swelling. The patient is placed in the left lateral decubitus position. Abducting the extended right leg against the physician's resistance reproduces the pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the pelvis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing pain in her right hip for 2 months. The pain is intermittent, presenting at the lateral side of the hip and radiating towards the thigh. It is aggravated while climbing stairs or lying on the right side. Two weeks ago, the patient was treated with a course of oral prednisone for exacerbation of asthma. Her current medications include formoterol-budesonide and albuterol inhalers. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows tenderness to palpation over the upper lateral part of the right thigh. There is no swelling. The patient is placed in the left lateral decubitus position. Abducting the extended right leg against the physician's resistance reproduces the pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the pelvis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Standing on the right leg most likely causes hip pain in this patient.
learning_objective: Recognize greater trochanteric pain syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Greater trochanteric pain syndrome (GTPS) results from tendinopathy at the attachment of the gluteus medius and/or minimus muscle. GTPS affects women more frequently and manifests with lateral thigh or hip pain near the great trochanter. Typical findings include tenderness to palpation over the greater trochanter, exacerbation of pain by lying on the affected side, and triggering of pain by resisted abduction, all of which are present in this patient. In patients with classic features of GTPS, imaging is not required to establish the diagnosis. X-ray is usually normal and essentially rules out bone involvement. Management of GTPS is mainly conservative and includes physical therapy and modified activities to strengthen the gluteal muscles without causing damage to the gluteal tendons from overexertion, as well as oral NSAIDs or glucocorticoid injections at the greater trochanter for pain.

Although femoroacetabular impingement typically presents with insidious groin pain, it may also occasionally manifest with lateral hip pain. However, hip tenderness on palpation is usually absent. Classical findings of the condition, such as pain with flexion, adduction, and internal rotation of the hip (positive impingement test), or limitation of internal rotation and/or flexion of the hip, are also not seen in this patient. Moreover, the x-ray would show a deep acetabular socket, acetabular retroversion, or a nonspherical femoral head, with or without evidence of labral tears and osteoarthritis.

Although meralgia paresthetica may present with pain in the outer thigh that is aggravated by climbing stairs and a normal pelvic x-ray, it is typically associated with tingling, burning, or numbness. Common risk factors for meralgia paresthetica include diabetes, obesity, pregnancy, trauma, or hip surgery, none of which are present in this patient.

Iliotibial band syndrome typically manifests with lateral knee pain, while hip pain is less commonly observed. Moreover, iliotibial band syndrome is an overuse injury that occurs mostly in runners or cyclists.

Although osteoarthritis of the hip may also manifest with hip pain that is exacerbated by climbing stairs, a pelvic x-ray would most likely show findings, such as narrowing of the joint space, osteophytes, and/or subchondral sclerosis, which this patient's x-ray does not show. Moreover, hip osteoarthritis is uncommon in patients younger than 50.

images.title: Illustration of right hip radiograph in osteoarthritis
images.description: AP viewFindings of osteoarthritis include irregular joint space narrowing (1), osteophytes (2), subchondral sclerosis (3), and subchondral cyst formation (4).

answers.explanation_why: A radiculopathy of the L4 nerve root as a result of an L3/L4 disk herniation can manifest with hip and thigh pain, as well normal findings on x-ray. However, patients would also have weakness of the hip flexors, and/or a history of lower back pain, neither of which are seen here. Moreover, the pain in patients with radiculopathy is typically aggravated by raising the extended leg (a positive straight leg raise test) and not by hip abduction.

Osteonecrosis of the femoral head can also cause hip pain. Although this patient has a history of steroid use, which is a risk factor for osteonecrosis of the femoral head, this condition usually develops after long-term steroid use, and not with a two-week course. Additionally, an x-ray would likely show abnormalities, such as osteopenia and microfractures of the subchondral bone, or a crescent sign (a subchondral line of radiolucency seen in late stages of the disease), none of which is seen here.

question_text: A 24-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe lower back pain for the past 2 days. The pain is constant and nonradiating, and he describes it as 7 out of 10 in intensity. The pain began after he helped a friend move into a new apartment. He has a history of intravenous heroin use.  He takes no medications.  His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 128/90 mm Hg. Examination shows old track marks on the cubital fossae bilaterally. His lumbar paraspinal muscles are firm and tense on palpation. There is no midline spinal tenderness. Flexing the hip and extending the knee while raising the leg to 70° on both sides does not cause pain. Sensation is not impaired. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 24-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe lower back pain for the past 2 days. The pain is constant and nonradiating, and he describes it as 7 out of 10 in intensity. The pain began after he helped a friend move into a new apartment. He has a history of intravenous heroin use. He takes no medications. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 128/90 mm Hg. Examination shows old track marks on the cubital fossae bilaterally. His lumbar paraspinal muscles are firm and tense on palpation. There is no midline spinal tenderness. Flexing the hip and extending the knee while raising the leg to 70° on both sides does not cause pain. Sensation is not impaired. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has acute back pain  without features of radiculopathy or myelopathy (e.g., shooting or shock-like pain, weakness, numbness) following a task that likely involved lifting heavy objects, which is consistent with acute lower back strain.
learning_objective: Recognize acute lower back strain, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Epidural glucocorticoid injections may provide modest symptomatic relief in patients with lumbosacral radiculopathy that persists for > 6 months. This patient has no signs of radiculopathy, and he has only had symptoms for 2 days, so epidural glucocorticoids are not indicated.

Although refraining from strenuous activity is prudent for back strain, strict bed rest is not recommended because this may actually lead to deconditioning and worse pain. Studies have shown that bed rest is associated with a longer recovery time compared to mild to moderate activity in patients with acute musculoskeletal lower back pain.

Analgesia, preferably with NSAIDs, and continuation of normal activities (except strenuous exercise) is the treatment of choice for acute musculoskeletal lower back pain. Almost all cases of musculoskeletal lower back pain resolve on their own within ∼ 6 weeks. Analgesia reduces discomfort, and mild to moderate activity is associated with better outcomes than bed rest. Further testing (e.g., MRI) should be considered in patients with back pain if there is high suspicion for a serious or urgent underlying cause (e.g., spinal infection) and in individuals whose symptoms have not significantly improved after ∼ 6 weeks. Muscle relaxants such as cyclobenzaprine or tizanidine can be used as alternatives or in combination with NSAIDs for the treatment of acute lower back pain.

MRI of the spine may be indicated in patients with back pain if there is high suspicion of a serious or urgent underlying cause (e.g., spinal infection) and in individuals whose symptoms have not significantly improved after ∼ 6 weeks. Although a history of IV drug use is a red flag for infection (e.g., epidural abscess), this patient has none of the typical features (e.g., fever, rigors, specific tender point, neurological deficits). This patient's recent history and physical examination strongly suggest acute musculoskeletal lower back pain.

Lumbar x-ray is indicated if a vertebral compression fracture is suspected. While lumbar compression fractures manifest with lower back pain, they usually occur in patients at risk of pathological fracture (e.g., > 50 years old, osteoporosis, or malignancy) or after significant trauma (e.g., motor vehicle collision) and cause midline point tenderness on exam. This patient is young, has no clear risk factors for compression fracture, did not experience significant trauma, and has no midline tenderness.

Broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy is indicated in patients if a bacterial cause of lower back pain is suspected (eg, epidural abscess, osteomyelitis). This patient is at increased risk of infection (history of IV drug use); however, he has no history of fever. Furthermore, patients with lower back pain caused by infection are typically more severely ill.

question_text: A 76-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter for evaluation of progressive cognitive decline and a 1-year history of incontinence. She was diagnosed with Alzheimer disease 5 years ago. The daughter reports that in the past year, her mother has become nonambulatory, can speak only a few intelligible words, and requires assistance with all activities of daily living. Over the past year, she has had decreased appetite and progressive dysphagia, resulting in a 12-kg (26-lb) weight loss. She has been hospitalized three times for aspiration pneumonia, and her diet now consists only of puréed food. She has no advance directives. The daughter says that she does not want her mother to return to the hospital again, but she is concerned about her ability to continue providing care alone. The patient has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include amlodipine and atorvastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. She appears malnourished but well groomed. The patient is oriented only to self. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 0/30, and Functional Assessment Staging Tool scale is 7/7. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of creatinine, urea nitrogen, TSH, and vitamin B_12 are within the reference ranges. Her serum albumin concentration is 3 g/dL. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 76-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter for evaluation of progressive cognitive decline and a 1-year history of incontinence. She was diagnosed with Alzheimer disease 5 years ago. The daughter reports that in the past year, her mother has become nonambulatory, can speak only a few intelligible words, and requires assistance with all activities of daily living. Over the past year, she has had decreased appetite and progressive dysphagia, resulting in a 12-kg (26-lb) weight loss. She has been hospitalized three times for aspiration pneumonia, and her diet now consists only of puréed food. She has no advance directives. The daughter says that she does not want her mother to return to the hospital again, but she is concerned about her ability to continue providing care alone. The patient has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include amlodipine and atorvastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. She appears malnourished but well groomed. The patient is oriented only to self. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 0/30, and Functional Assessment Staging Tool scale is 7/7. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of creatinine, urea nitrogen, TSH, and vitamin B12 are within the reference ranges. Her serum albumin concentration is 3 g/dL. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Because mortality risk prediction in advanced dementia is difficult, decisions about end-of-life care should include the preferences of the patient and their family.
learning_objective: Recognize advanced dementia with poor prognosis, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Short-term rehabilitation is generally indicated for patients who require rehabilitation and/or further medical care and who no longer require inpatient care (e.g., a patient treated for pneumonia who is weak from hospitalization but whose infection is cured). This patient's Alzheimer disease is severe, chronic, progressive, and incurable, so rehabilitation would not be beneficial.

Opioids (e.g., oxycodone) are indicated to treat pain in patients with terminal illness (e.g., bone pain in a patient with metastatic cancer). While this patient has a terminal illness, there is no evidence that she is in pain, so opioids are not indicated.

This nonambulatory patient with severe cognitive impairment, total functional dependence, incontinence, and dysphagia causing frequent aspiration and significant weight loss, has severe end-stage Alzheimer disease. A history of nutritional decline and recurrent hospitalization for aspiration pneumonia indicates a poor prognosis, often with life expectancy measured in months. Hospice care is appropriate when life expectancy is estimated at 6 months or less, and a do-not-resuscitate order is not required. Home hospice provides comfort-focused care and support for caregivers, aligning with both the patient's prognosis and their family's goals and preferences.

The Functional Assessment Staging Tool scale evaluates dementia progression across seven stages of functional decline, with stage 7 indicating very severe dementia.

Tube feeding in advanced dementia does not improve survival, prevent aspiration pneumonia, or increase quality of life. This approach may increase discomfort, agitation, and risk of complications (e.g., infection, tube dislodgement). Comfort feeding with puréed food, which this patient already receives, is preferred.

Palliative care focuses on symptom management and quality of life in serious illness, and it can be provided alongside curative treatment at any stage. Inpatient palliative care is reserved for individuals with acute, uncontrolled symptoms (e.g., severe pain, agitation, uncontrolled dyspnea) that cannot be managed outside of a hospital. This patient has no acute symptoms requiring crisis intervention.

question_text: Six days after undergoing surgical repair of a hip fracture, a 71-year-old man is agitated and confused. Last night, he was restrained after multiple attempts to leave his room. His overnight nurse reported that she observed several periods of rest followed by sudden episodes of agitation without a clear trigger. He has hypertension and COPD. He previously smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years but quit 10 years ago. He drinks one glass of whiskey per day. His current medications include oxycodone, hydrochlorothiazide, and salmeterol. He appears agitated. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 141/84 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination shows a prolonged expiratory phase but no other abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows inattentiveness and no focal findings. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. During the examination, the patient becomes violent, pulls out his intravenous line, and attempts to leave the room. He does not respond to verbal deescalation techniques, and soft restraints are used. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: Six days after undergoing surgical repair of a hip fracture, a 71-year-old man is agitated and confused. Last night, he was restrained after multiple attempts to leave his room. His overnight nurse reported that she observed several periods of rest followed by sudden episodes of agitation without a clear trigger. He has hypertension and COPD. He previously smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years but quit 10 years ago. He drinks one glass of whiskey per day. His current medications include oxycodone, hydrochlorothiazide, and salmeterol. He appears agitated. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 141/84 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination shows a prolonged expiratory phase but no other abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows inattentiveness and no focal findings. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. During the examination, the patient becomes violent, pulls out his intravenous line, and attempts to leave the room. He does not respond to verbal deescalation techniques, and soft restraints are used. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The patient's age, recent surgery, immobilization, and opioid use place him at high risk for delirium.
learning_objective: Recognize delirium with refractory agitation, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: A urine culture may be indicated if a urinary tract infection is the suspected underlying cause of a patient's delirium. However, because this patient is agitated and violent, another step in management is indicated before conducting diagnostic studies.

A chest x-ray may be indicated if pneumonia is the suspected underlying cause of a patient's delirium. However, this patient is afebrile, and his lungs are clear to auscultation, making pneumonia unlikely. Also, obtaining a chest x-ray in an agitated and violent patient is difficult. Another step in management is indicated before conducting diagnostic studies.

answers.content: Obtain CT scan of the head
answers.explanation_why: Neuroimaging (e.g., CT scan of the head) may be indicated if an intracranial condition (e.g., stroke) is the suspected cause of a patient's delirium. However, this patient has no focal findings that suggest intracranial pathology. Also, obtaining a CT scan in an agitated and violent patient is difficult. Another step in management is indicated before conducting diagnostic studies.

Benzodiazepines (e.g., lorazepam) are deliriogenic and are typically reserved for patients with delirium due to alcohol or benzodiazepine withdrawal. Although this patient's drinking pattern increases his risk of developing alcohol withdrawal delirium, this condition usually occurs 72–96 hours after the last drink and typically manifests with hallucinations and tremors.

The initial management of delirium includes nonpharmacologic supportive measures (e.g., reorienting the patient to time, place, and person). In patients with agitation, additional measures, such as deescalation techniques, are used. Coercive measures (e.g., physical restraints) may be necessary if the patient is actively violent. A calming medication should be used before or immediately after applying restraints to reduce the risk of injury and negative psychological consequences. An antipsychotic (e.g., haloperidol) is the calming medication of choice for refractory agitation in patients with delirium. After adequate sedation has been achieved, restraints should be removed immediately.

question_text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of chronic abdominal pain that developed after starting a job at a law firm. She also has abdominal bloating and constipation that started 2 weeks ago. She has had no pain with defecation or change in stool form or appearance. She is upset because she has seen two other physicians who performed tests but were unable to make a diagnosis. The patient is currently on sick leave but would like to return to work as soon as possible. She often worries about having a gastric ulcer that may perforate and insists on getting an endoscopy. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She reports that she is under significant pressure from her managers because of frequent performance evaluations. She has a history of childhood asthma. She takes multivitamins and glucosamine daily to prevent arthritis. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is mildly distended and slightly tender. The remainder of the examination, including a neurologic examination, shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Fecal occult blood test and urea breath test are negative. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of chronic abdominal pain that developed after starting a job at a law firm. She also has abdominal bloating and constipation that started 2 weeks ago. She has had no pain with defecation or change in stool form or appearance. She is upset because she has seen two other physicians who performed tests but were unable to make a diagnosis. The patient is currently on sick leave but would like to return to work as soon as possible. She often worries about having a gastric ulcer that may perforate and insists on getting an endoscopy. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She reports that she is under significant pressure from her managers because of frequent performance evaluations. She has a history of childhood asthma. She takes multivitamins and glucosamine daily to prevent arthritis. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is mildly distended and slightly tender. The remainder of the examination, including a neurologic examination, shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Fecal occult blood test and urea breath test are negative. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
hint: Individuals with this condition typically have a history of visiting multiple physicians.
learning_objective: Recognize somatic symptom disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Individuals with adjustment disorder present with a maladaptive emotional and/or behavioral response within 3 months of a stressful event (e.g., cancer diagnosis). Common features include excessive distress and impaired social functioning. Although this patient's symptoms began after starting a new job, her physical findings (e.g., abdominal distention) make adjustment disorder unlikely.

Illness anxiety disorder is diagnosed in individuals with a persistent fear of having or developing an illness in the absence of physical symptoms. Patients may also show maladaptive behavior, such as frequently changing physicians, making it an important differential diagnosis in this patient. Although she spends considerable time worrying about her health, her anxiety is caused by distinct physical symptoms, which are not expected in illness anxiety disorder.

Patients with malingering typically present with vague symptoms and may insist on undergoing extensive medical evaluation. Symptoms in malingering are intentionally fabricated or exaggerated for secondary gain (e.g., in order to get time off from work). There is no evidence that this patient's symptoms are feigned or exaggerated, and she wants to return to work, making another diagnosis more likely.

Individuals with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) present with recurrent, nonspecific changes in bowel movements and abdominal symptoms (e.g., diffuse pain, pressure). Diagnostic criteria for IBS consist of abdominal pain on at least 1 day each week during the previous 3 months that is accompanied by at least 2 of the following features: pain with defecation, change in stool frequency, or change in stool form or appearance. Although this patient has had abdominal pain for a year and also reports new-onset constipation, which may manifest with changes in stool frequency and form, constipation has only been present for 2 weeks, meaning that the diagnostic criteria for IBS are not currently fulfilled.

Individuals with functional neurological disorder present with a range of neurological symptoms (e.g., altered sensory function, paralysis with no anatomical pattern) that cause significant psychosocial impairment and that cannot be attributed to a neurological condition. Unlike this patient, individuals with functional neurological symptom disorder are not preoccupied with their health. In addition, this patient does not report any neurological symptoms.

Somatic symptom disorder manifests with one or more physical symptoms that cause significant distress and/or interfere with daily functioning, typically lasting > 6 months. The diagnostic criteria include at least one of the following: disproportionate thoughts, feelings, and/or behaviors concerning one's health, excessive anxiety about illness, and inordinate time or resources spent on health concerns. Incidence of somatic symptom disorder is higher in women and in those with a history of chronic childhood illness (e.g., asthma). After ruling out any treatable medical conditions, management consists of reducing unnecessary tests and procedures by scheduling regular appointments and establishing a therapeutic alliance with a single primary care physician. Psychotherapy (e.g., cognitive behavioral therapy) may be helpful to treat any underlying psychological causes (e.g., stress) and comorbid psychiatric conditions.

Individuals with factitious disorder typically have a history of seeking care from multiple providers and significant exposure to a healthcare environment (e.g., because of childhood illness) and are willing to undergo invasive treatments. Factitious disorder is characterized by the intentional falsification of an illness and/or its symptoms (e.g., factitious hypoglycemia due to surreptitious insulin use) in order to assume the sick role. There is no evidence of deceptive or attention-seeking behavior by this patient, and her symptoms appear to be genuine.

question_text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of persistent pain in her right shoulder. The pain is localized to the top of the shoulder and is worse with movement. She has stiffness in the right shoulder that is worse in the morning and usually lasts 20 minutes. The patient reports that she is unable to brush her hair and has stopped going to her regular tennis lessons because of the pain. She does not recall any fall or trauma. When her right arm is passively abducted in an arc, there is pain between 60 and 120 degrees of abduction. When asked to lower the right arm slowly from 90 degrees of abduction, she is unable to hold her arm up and it drops to her side. Passive range of motion is normal. Injection of 5 mL of 1% lidocaine into the right subacromial space does not relieve the pain or improve active range of motion of the right arm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of persistent pain in her right shoulder. The pain is localized to the top of the shoulder and is worse with movement. She has stiffness in the right shoulder that is worse in the morning and usually lasts 20 minutes. The patient reports that she is unable to brush her hair and has stopped going to her regular tennis lessons because of the pain. She does not recall any fall or trauma. When her right arm is passively abducted in an arc, there is pain between 60 and 120 degrees of abduction. When asked to lower the right arm slowly from 90 degrees of abduction, she is unable to hold her arm up and it drops to her side. Passive range of motion is normal. Injection of 5 mL of 1% lidocaine into the right subacromial space does not relieve the pain or improve active range of motion of the right arm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The patient's inability to hold up her arm at 90 degrees of abduction indicates a positive drop arm test.
learning_objective: Recognize a rotator cuff tear.

answers.explanation_why: Cervical radiculopathy is most often caused by spondylosis or a herniated disc in the cervical spine and may cause neck, shoulder, and/or arm pain. However, cervical radiculopathy is typically characterized by radiating pain and paresthesias and pain with passive abduction of the shoulder would not be expected.

Subacromial impingement syndrome, rotator cuff tendinopathy, and rotator cuff tear can all manifest with pain exacerbated by overhead activity. This patient's pain with passive abduction between 60 and 120 degrees suggests impingement and/or rotator cuff disease, and the weakness seen on the drop arm test further narrows the diagnosis to a tear in the supraspinatus muscle of the rotator cuff. It is important to note that the sensitivity and specificity of these physical examination maneuvers are limited, especially with regard to rotator cuff tears; musculoskeletal ultrasound and/or MRI should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

images.title: Rotator cuff tear
images.description: The top image shows a cross-section of the shoulder joint.The bottom images show the progression of a degenerative rotator cuff tear. Repetitive overhead movement and/or anatomical variants of the acromion can result in inflammation of the subacromial bursa and rotator cuff tendons (left). This may progress to degeneration of the bursa and tendons (middle). As a result, the tendon fibers are less elastic and prone to tear, resulting in a rotator cuff tear (right). The supraspinatus tendon is most commonly affected.

answers.explanation_why: Calcific tendinitis of the rotator cuff can also manifest with shoulder pain exacerbated by overhead activity, as seen in this patient. However, this patient's pain with passive movement of the arm, positive drop arm test, and negative lidocaine injection test are not consistent with calcific tendinitis.

Subacromial bursitis is usually due to repetitive overhead movement. It may result in subacromial impingement syndrome and can progress to adhesive capsulitis if movement is limited by pain for a prolonged period of time. Although subacromial bursitis is also characterized by pain with abduction, as seen in this patient, it would not cause weakness.

Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is most common in women > 50 years old and can manifest with shoulder pain and morning stiffness. However, pain from PMR is usually bilateral, diffuse, and accompanied by neck pain and/or pelvic girdle pain. Although this patient complains of morning stiffness, PMR is characterized by prolonged morning stiffness (> 45 minutes). Additionally, this patient's weakness on examination is not consistent with PMR.

Biceps tendinitis is usually due to repetitive lifting or pulling activities. It typically manifests with anterior shoulder pain that radiates down the anterior upper arm. The pain with passive abduction and weakness seen in this patient is not consistent with biceps tendinitis.

Rotator cuff tendinitis is common in individuals who engage in repetitive overhead activities and may also manifest with shoulder pain and weakness exacerbated by activity. The pain associated with rotator cuff tendinitis should resolve with subacromial lidocaine injection. This patient's continued pain and limited range of motion suggest another diagnosis.

Adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder) typically manifests with shoulder pain and limited active range of motion which typically does not improve significantly with a lidocaine injection test. However, passive range of motion is typically restricted in patients with frozen shoulders, making this diagnosis unlikely.

question_text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. He reports right hip pain and numbness along the right thigh. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to light touch over a small area of the medial thigh. X-rays of the pelvis show a displaced pelvic ring fracture. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. He reports right hip pain and numbness along the right thigh. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to light touch over a small area of the medial thigh. X-rays of the pelvis show a displaced pelvic ring fracture. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This man has a pelvic ring fracture with decreased sensation over a small area of the right medial thigh. This is consistent with an obturator nerve injury.
learning_objective: Recognize obturator nerve injury, and recall its motor function deficit.

answers.content: Sensory deficit of the dorsal foot
answers.explanation_why: Sensory deficits of the dorsal foot can be caused by injury to the superficial peroneal branch of the common peroneal nerve, which provides sensory cutaneous innervation to the lateral lower leg and dorsal aspect of the foot. However, injury to the common peroneal nerve or its branches would not cause decreased sensation in the medial thigh.

Impaired hip extension can occur in the setting of hip dislocation or hip arthroplasty. The muscles involved in hip extension include the gluteus maximus (innervated by the inferior gluteal nerve), and the semitendinosus and semimembranosus (both innervated by the sciatic nerve). Neither the inferior gluteal nerve nor the sciatic nerve provides sensory innervation to the medial thigh.

Impaired dorsiflexion of the foot can be seen in common peroneal nerve injury, which typically occurs in the setting of fibular head fractures or external compression of the common peroneal nerve at the level of the fibular head. The branches of the common peroneal nerve provide sensory innervation to the first dorsal web space and the lateral lower leg and dorsal foot. Injury to this nerve would not explain the patient's decreased sensation in the medial thigh.

Impaired extension of the knee can occur following injury to the femoral nerve, which innervates the quadriceps muscles. Although femoral nerve injury can be caused by direct trauma (e.g., fracture, compression from a hematoma) it is unlikely to be the cause of this patient's sensory deficit on the medial thigh because sensory fibers from the femoral nerve also provide cutaneous innervation to the medial lower leg and foot.

Absence of the cremasteric reflex is seen in patients with injury to the genitofemoral nerve, as the nerve provides motor innervation to the cremaster muscle. The genitofemoral nerve also provides sensory cutaneous innervation to the scrotum in men and to the mons pubis and labia majora in women; there are also cutaneous branches to the proximal aspect of the anteromedial thigh. This patient presents with decreased sensation to the medial thigh, which could be seen in genitofemoral nerve injury. However, pelvic ring fractures are not associated with genitofemoral nerve injuries.

Pelvic ring fracture is a common cause of obturator nerve injury. In addition to providing sensory cutaneous innervation to a small area of the medial thigh, the obturator nerve also provides motor innervation to the hip adductor muscles in the medial compartment of the thigh. Thus, injury to the nerve can result in impaired adduction of the hip.

question_text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening lower back pain. The pain radiates down the right leg to the lateral side of the foot. She has had no trauma, urinary incontinence, or fever. An MRI of the lumbar spine shows disk degeneration and herniation compressing the S1 nerve root. Which of the following is the most likely finding on physical examination?
content_preview: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening lower back pain. The pain radiates down the right leg to the lateral side of the foot. She has had no trauma, urinary incontinence, or fever. An MRI of the lumbar spine shows disk degeneration and herniation compressing the S1 nerve root. Which of the following is the most likely finding on physical examination?
hint: S1 radiculopathy causes motor deficits in the gastrocnemius muscle.
learning_objective: Recognize S1 radiculopathy, and recall its effect on reflexes.

answers.explanation_why: Difficulty walking on heels (e.g., foot drop) is consistent with an injury to the L5 nerve roots (i.e., L5 radiculopathy). In addition, L5 radiculopathy would cause a sensory deficit extending along the dorsolateral thigh, the lateral side of the knee, lower leg, and dorsum of the foot and big toe.

An absent patellar reflex is consistent with an injury to the L3 and L4 nerve roots (i.e., L3 and L4 radiculopathy). In addition, L3 radiculopathy would cause sensory deficits of the anterolateral area of the thigh. L4 radiculopathy would cause a sensory deficit extending along the anterolateral thigh, the area over the patella, the medial aspect of the leg, and the medial malleolus.

answers.content: Diminished sensation of the anus and genitalia
answers.explanation_why: Diminished sensation of the anus and the genitalia is seen in cauda equina syndrome. Although patients typically present with asymmetric, unilateral radicular pain in the lower limb dermatomes (due to a lesion below the level of L2), there are usually numerous spinal nerves (L3–S5) involved rather than an isolated nerve root (S1 dermatome) as seen in this patient. Furthermore, other expected findings (e.g., saddle block anesthesia, fecal incontinence, urinary incontinence or retention) are lacking in this patient.

S1 radiculopathy is caused by compression of the S1 spinal nerve root and can manifest with a weak Achilles tendon reflex. The S1 nerve root controls plantar flexion through the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles, so weakness in these muscles can lead to a diminished Achilles tendon reflex and impaired toe walking. Additionally, the S1 nerve root controls sensation in the dorsolateral aspect of the thigh, the posterior calf, and the lateral side of the foot, which explains this patient's radiating pain in these regions.

answers.content: Diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh
answers.explanation_why: Diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh is consistent with an injury to the L3 nerve root (i.e., L3 radiculopathy). In addition, L3 radiculopathy would cause a sensory deficit of the anterolateral area of the thigh, as well as weakness of hip flexion, hip adduction, and knee extension.

question_text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of progressively worsening pain on the outer side of her left elbow. She does not recall any trauma to the area. The patient plays badminton recreationally. Examination shows tenderness over the lateral surface of the left distal humerus. The pain is reproduced by supinating the forearm against resistance. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's pain?
content_preview: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of progressively worsening pain on the outer side of her left elbow. She does not recall any trauma to the area. The patient plays badminton recreationally. Examination shows tenderness over the lateral surface of the left distal humerus. The pain is reproduced by supinating the forearm against resistance. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's pain?
hint: Progressively worsening pain near the lateral epicondyle in a racket sports enthusiast suggests lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow).
learning_objective: Recognize lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow) due to repeated wrist extension.

answers.explanation_why: Excessive bone stress from submaximal loading is responsible for stress fractures. The most common site for stress fractures near the elbow is the olecranon process, and individuals involved in racket sports are at increased risk of developing this overuse injury. However, patients with olecranon stress fractures typically present with pain over the posterior surface of the elbow and exacerbation of pain with extension of the forearm against resistance. Given the pain on the lateral surface of the forearm and exacerbation of pain with wrist extension against resistance seen here, a different diagnosis is likely.

Compression neuropathies that can occur at the elbow include cubital tunnel syndrome, pronator teres syndrome, and posterior interosseous nerve syndrome. Although individuals who practice racket sports are at increased risk of developing these conditions, a compression neuropathy would typically result in distal weakness in the affected arm. Cubital tunnel syndrome and pronator teres syndrome would also result in sensory loss and/or paresthesias.

Compression of the posterior interosseous nerve within the radial tunnel occasionally results in pain on the lateral surface of the elbow without motor weakness, sensory deficits, or paresthesias (radial tunnel syndrome). In approximately 5% of patients, radial tunnel syndrome occurs in conjunction with lateral epicondylitis. However, in radial tunnel syndrome, pain typically affects the dorsal aspect of the proximal forearm rather than the distal humerus.

Repetitive elbow flexion and extension, which occurs while playing racket sports, can cause elbow pain due to olecranon bursitis. However, the pain associated with olecranon bursitis would be localized to the posterior surface of the elbow, and swelling would usually occur at the tip of the elbow. The more likely cause of this patient's symptoms is lateral epicondylitis, which is not the result of bursitis.

The lateral epicondyle is the common origin of the wrist extensors. Lateral epicondylitis is caused by activities, e.g., racket sports such as tennis and badminton, that involve repetitive wrist extension and/or repetitive forearm supination/pronation with the elbow nearly fully extended. In patients with lateral epicondylitis, the pain can be exacerbated by resisted supination, resisted wrist extension, and tight grasping of objects. The most sensitive imaging finding is thickening and edema of the tendinous origin of the extensor carpi radialis brevis.

Repeated wrist flexion can cause medial epicondylitis, which can affect individuals involved in racket sports and manifests with elbow pain. However, the pain would be present on the medial surface of the elbow and it would be exacerbated by forearm pronation and/or wrist flexion. Moreover, medial epicondylitis is 5–10 times less common than lateral epicondylitis.

question_text: A 34-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after she sustained a spinal cord injury and pelvic fracture following a motorcycle accident. She undergoes surgery and is transferred to the rehabilitation unit for therapy. During her rehabilitation, she notices frequent dribbling of urine despite the absence of an urge to urinate. She is 181 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (198 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 2/5 muscle strength in the bilateral lower extremities, decreased sensation in the lower extremities, decreased rectal tone, and a palpable suprapubic mass. Genital examination shows no abnormalities. Straight intermittent catheterization is performed and she no longer dribbles urine for the next few hours. Urinalysis shows negative leukocyte esterase and negative nitrites. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause for this patient's urinary incontinence?
content_preview: A 34-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after she sustained a spinal cord injury and pelvic fracture following a motorcycle accident. She undergoes surgery and is transferred to the rehabilitation unit for therapy. During her rehabilitation, she notices frequent dribbling of urine despite the absence of an urge to urinate. She is 181 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (198 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 2/5 muscle strength in the bilateral lower extremities, decreased sensation in the lower extremities, decreased rectal tone, and a palpable suprapubic mass. Genital examination shows no abnormalities. Straight intermittent catheterization is performed and she no longer dribbles urine for the next few hours. Urinalysis shows negative leukocyte esterase and negative nitrites. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause for this patient's urinary incontinence?
hint: A history of intermittent dribbling of urine not associated with increased intraabdominal pressure (e.g., laughing, sneezing, coughing, exercising) or an urge to urinate is suggestive of overflow incontinence.
learning_objective: Recognize underactivity of the detrusor muscle.

answers.explanation_why: Urethral hypermobility can cause stress incontinence, especially in women. Urethral hypermobility can occur in patients with pelvic fractures and/or following pelvic surgery due to damage to the pelvic floor muscles. However, stress incontinence is characterized by urinary leakage during activities that increase intraabdominal pressure (e.g., laughing, sneezing, coughing, exercising).

Underactivity of the detrusor muscle is one of the causes of overflow incontinence. Patients with an acute spinal cord injury (SCI) can have spinal shock, which is a combination of decreased sensation, flaccid paralysis, and autonomic dysfunction below the level of an SCI. Autonomic dysfunction results in parasympathetic inactivation and a consequent atonic bladder. Patients with SCI become unaware of bladder filling and feel no urge to void, resulting in an overfilled and overdistended bladder that is palpable in the suprapubic region. When intravesical pressure rises above bladder outlet resistance, involuntary dribbling of urine occurs. SCI at or below the sacral micturition center can also cause overflow incontinence due to damage to the lower motor neurons that form part of the micturition reflex arc. Urinary retention in patients with an atonic bladder is best managed by clean intermittent catheterization.

Another cause of overflow incontinence is bladder outflow obstruction (e.g., benign prostatic hyperplasia in men or pelvic organ prolapse and uterine fibroids in women). Bladder outlet obstruction is often associated with hesitancy and a sensation of incomplete emptying.

Increased bladder sensitivity results from overactivity of the detrusor muscle, which causes urge incontinence. Urge incontinence is characterized by a strong urge to void that usually precedes or accompanies urine leakage.

Intrinsic sphincteric deficiency can cause stress incontinence, and it can occur in patients with pelvic fractures and/or following pelvic surgery. However, stress incontinence is characterized by urinary leakage during activities that increase intraabdominal pressure (e.g., laughing, sneezing, coughing, exercising).

Complete loss of sphincter function can cause total incontinence, which can result from a spinal cord injury and manifest with involuntary urine loss without an urge to urinate. This patient's urinary incontinence, however, only occurs when her bladder is full (she no longer dribbles urine for a few hours after catheterization), whereas total incontinence is characterized by continuous urinary leakage.

question_text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of progressive muscle pain. The pain started in the shoulder muscles and then spread to the arms, back, and legs. She often feels stiff in the morning but does not have significant joint pain. She reports that she has had trouble sleeping because of the pain and cannot concentrate during the day. Medical history is remarkable for major depressive disorder. Her only medication is sertraline. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She appears tired. Examination shows tenderness in the arms and legs and along the axial skeleton. There is no joint swelling. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13.4 g/dL, an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 10 mm/h, and a creatine kinase concentration of 55 U/L. Results of other laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of progressive muscle pain. The pain started in the shoulder muscles and then spread to the arms, back, and legs. She often feels stiff in the morning but does not have significant joint pain. She reports that she has had trouble sleeping because of the pain and cannot concentrate during the day. Medical history is remarkable for major depressive disorder. Her only medication is sertraline. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She appears tired. Examination shows tenderness in the arms and legs and along the axial skeleton. There is no joint swelling. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13.4 g/dL, an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 10 mm/h, and a creatine kinase concentration of 55 U/L. Results of other laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's history of chronic, widespread muscle tenderness, morning stiffness, fatigue, cognitive dysfunction (difficulty concentrating), and sleep disturbances, in conjunction with normal laboratory studies, suggests fibromyalgia (FM). FM mostly affects women between the second and fifth decade of life and is often associated with psychiatric disorders, such as depression.
learning_objective: Recognize fibromyalgia, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Electromyography (EMG) is used in the diagnosis of neurogenic and myopathic disorders, such as inflammatory myopathies, which manifest with muscle tenderness. However, inflammatory markers (e.g., ESR) and muscle enzymes (e.g., creatinine kinase) are typically elevated in inflammatory myopathies. This patient most likely has FM, in which EMG is not needed to establish the diagnosis.

Muscle biopsy is used in the diagnosis of inflammatory myopathies, such as polymyositis (PM) and dermatomyositis (DM), which manifest with muscle tenderness. However, inflammatory markers (e.g., ESR) and muscle enzymes (e.g., creatinine kinase) are typically elevated in inflammatory myopathies. This patient most likely has FM, in which muscle biopsy is not recommended.

Prednisone is used in the treatment of autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and polymyalgia rheumatica (PR). SLE affects women more often than men and can manifest with myalgias and fatigue. However, this patient does not have other common findings in SLE, such as skin involvement (e.g., the typical butterfly rash), joint pain, fever, and weight loss. PR mainly affects women older than 50 years of age and manifests with stiffness and pain in the shoulders, hips, or neck, as well as systemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, malaise, and depressed mood). In contrast to what is seen in this patient, ESR is typically significantly elevated.

Although ketorolac is often used in the treatment of moderate to severe pain, treatment with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and/or acetaminophen has not been proven effective in patients with FM and should, therefore, be avoided.

Regular exercise can reduce pain and improve functional capacity in patients with FM; cardiovascular training (e.g., swimming, walking, cycling) is recommended. Patients with FM should be advised to increase daily physical exercise gradually and that it is normal to initially experience a temporary worsening of myalgias. In addition, initial management of FM should include patient education (including reassurance about the disease and its prognosis and the importance of nonpharmacological measures such as sleep hygiene), treatment of comorbidities (e.g., mood and sleep disorders), and pharmacotherapy with low-dose tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline). Cyclobenzaprine, selective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (e.g., duloxetine), or anticonvulsants (e.g., pregabalin, gabapentin) can also be used as initial pharmacotherapy.
Opioid therapy (e.g., with oxycodone) has not been proven effective in the treatment of chronic pain in patients with FM and should, therefore, be avoided.

question_text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of numbness and weakness in her right hand for the past 4 weeks. During this time, she has also had intermittent pain in her right arm for which treatment with ibuprofen has provided some relief. She is a professional tennis player but has not been able to practice because her symptoms get worse when she swings the racquet overhead. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Her only medication is a vitamin supplement. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 110/73 mm Hg. Physical examination of the right hand shows decreased sensation to light touch in the 4^th and 5^th fingers. Repeated opening and closing of the hands with the arms raised above the shoulder causes pain and a sensation of heaviness in the right arm. Percussion over the right medial epicondyle of the humerus does not reproduce the symptoms. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of numbness and weakness in her right hand for the past 4 weeks. During this time, she has also had intermittent pain in her right arm for which treatment with ibuprofen has provided some relief. She is a professional tennis player but has not been able to practice because her symptoms get worse when she swings the racquet overhead. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Her only medication is a vitamin supplement. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 110/73 mm Hg. Physical examination of the right hand shows decreased sensation to light touch in the 4th and 5th fingers. Repeated opening and closing of the hands with the arms raised above the shoulder causes pain and a sensation of heaviness in the right arm. Percussion over the right medial epicondyle of the humerus does not reproduce the symptoms. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The distribution of paresthesia and pain in this patient's right hand suggests a lesion involving the C8 and T1 nerves. In addition, the positive Roos stress test (arm heaviness with repeated opening and closing of the hands) is suggestive of neurogenic thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS).
learning_objective: Recognize neurogenic thoracic outlet syndrome, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Upper trunk decompression is used in the treatment of upper trunk brachial plexus compression, which typically causes Erb palsy and manifests with pain and paresthesia. However, the paresthesia usually develops along the lateral aspects of the arm, forearm, and/or hand (C5–C6 dermatomes), not the 4^th and 5^th digits. Moreover, patients with Erb palsy typically present with an internally rotated and adducted arm, extended forearm, and a flexed wrist (“waiter's tip posture”).

images.title: Waiter's tip deformity in Erb palsy

answers.explanation_why: Epidural glucocorticoid injections can be used to treat cervical radiculopathy, which typically manifests with pain, weakness, and paresthesia in the distribution of affected nerve roots. If the C8–T1 spinal roots are affected, pain and paresthesia develop in the 4^th and 5^th digits. However, patients with cervical radiculopathy will have an improvement in their symptoms with overhead arm elevation, and the Roos stress test is typically negative. Although an epidural glucocorticoid injection might relieve this patient's pain, it is not the next most appropriate step in management.

Elbow immobilization is used in the treatment of cubital tunnel syndrome, which can manifest with paresthesia in the 4^th and 5^th digits. However, patients with cubital tunnel syndrome do not have pain or heaviness in the arm that worsens when raised above the shoulders. In addition, this condition is associated with a positive Tinel test.

Volar splinting can be employed in the treatment of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS), which typically manifests with pain and paresthesia in the hand and can worsen with prolonged overhead hand elevation (positive hand elevation test). However, median nerve compression causes paresthesia in the 1^st, 2^nd, and 3^rd digits, rather than the 4^th and 5^th digits. Moreover, this patient's upper arm pain and positive Roos stress test are not consistent with CTS.

images.title: Carpal tunnel syndrome
images.description: Carpal tunnel syndrome is caused by compression of the median nerve by the transverse carpal ligament (flexor retinaculum).It typically manifests with sensory disturbances (pain, tingling, and numbness) in the area innervated by the median nerve distal to the carpal tunnel. Symptoms are typically worse at night. Severe compression of the median nerve can also cause motor symptoms (e.g., thenar muscle weakness and atrophy).

answers.explanation_why: Physical therapy is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient with neurogenic TOS. Therapy exercises should focus on strengthening shoulder muscles, stretching, and postural correction while sitting and standing in order to reduce pressure on the neurovascular structures in the thoracic outlet. Adjunctive therapies include NSAIDs for analgesia and weight reduction. If conservative treatment fails, thoracic outlet decompression surgery may be considered.

images.title: Thoracic outlet syndrome secondary to hyperabduction
images.description: Hyperabduction of the arm can lead to compression of the neurovascular structures under the coracoid process through the pectoralis minor muscle.

question_text: Two weeks after undergoing below-knee amputation of the left leg, a 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of episodic sharp, shooting, and burning pain below the amputation site. She is in the military reserve and was involved in active combat 2 weeks ago, during which she sustained multiple gunshot wounds to her left lower leg resulting in irreversible limb ischemia. She is currently taking oral acetaminophen, which has provided minimal pain relief. The patient has a history of bronchial asthma for which she uses an albuterol inhaler. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 123/75 mm Hg. Physical examination of the residual limb shows mild erythema and drainage of a scant amount of serous fluid from the sutured wound. Muscle strength in the hip and upper leg is normal bilaterally. Sensation to pain and temperature is normal in the left upper leg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: Two weeks after undergoing below-knee amputation of the left leg, a 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of episodic sharp, shooting, and burning pain below the amputation site. She is in the military reserve and was involved in active combat 2 weeks ago, during which she sustained multiple gunshot wounds to her left lower leg resulting in irreversible limb ischemia. She is currently taking oral acetaminophen, which has provided minimal pain relief. The patient has a history of bronchial asthma for which she uses an albuterol inhaler. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 123/75 mm Hg. Physical examination of the residual limb shows mild erythema and drainage of a scant amount of serous fluid from the sutured wound. Muscle strength in the hip and upper leg is normal bilaterally. Sensation to pain and temperature is normal in the left upper leg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's reporting of new-onset neuropathic pain in her left lower limb despite having undergone left-sided below-knee amputation two weeks ago suggests phantom limb pain.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for phantom limb pain.

answers.explanation_why: Surgical revision is indicated in postsurgical complications, such as residual limb infection, scar formation, or seroma. This patient's residual limb shows mild erythema and warmth of the overlying skin, which is normal during the first two weeks after surgery. Furthermore, she does not have any systemic signs or symptoms of an infection.

Ibuprofen, a nonopioid analgesic, is one of the preferred first-line treatments for mild to moderate pain. This patient's pain symptoms are more consistent with neuropathic pain, for which ibuprofen is not typically effective. Also, this patient's asthma limits the use of ibuprofen and other NSAIDs as these drugs can precipitate bronchoconstriction.

Spinal cord stimulation is a neuromodulation technique used to relieve chronic neuropathic pain (i.e, lasting > 6 months). It can be used as a second-line treatment for phantom limb pain. As this patient has only had pain for three days, other conservative modalities should be attempted before considering a spinal cord stimulator implant.

Opioid analgesics (e.g., oxycodone) can be used to treat moderate to severe pain. For patients with neuropathic pain, other forms of pharmacotherapy should be attempted first and opioid analgesics should be used as a last resort.

Certain anticonvulsants (e.g., gabapentin) and antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline) can be used to treat neuropathic pain, including phantom limb pain. Because there is insufficient research on treatment for phantom limb pain, a multimodal approach is typically recommended. Other forms of first-line treatment for phantom limb pain include mirror therapy, transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation, and pharmacotherapy with NMDA receptor antagonists. Note that phantom limb pain can only be diagnosed after the exclusion of other causes of stump pain (e.g., infection, ischemia, post-surgical neuroma).
