question_text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of right knee pain. The pain started suddenly when he collided with the catcher while sliding into home plate during a baseball game. It is sharp and constant and the patient has not been able to bear any weight on his right leg since then. He has no history of serious illness and his only medication is a creatine supplement that he takes to build up muscle. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a swollen right knee that is tender to palpation along the anterior aspects. He is unable to extend his knee against gravity. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. X-rays of his right knee show an effusion and the patella located proximal to the femoral condyles; there is no fracture. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of right knee pain. The pain started suddenly when he collided with the catcher while sliding into home plate during a baseball game. It is sharp and constant and the patient has not been able to bear any weight on his right leg since then. He has no history of serious illness and his only medication is a creatine supplement that he takes to build up muscle. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a swollen right knee that is tender to palpation along the anterior aspects. He is unable to extend his knee against gravity. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. X-rays of his right knee show an effusion and the patella located proximal to the femoral condyles; there is no fracture. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's knee x-ray findings are consistent with a high-riding patella.
learning_objective: Recognize a patellar tendon tear.

answers.explanation_why:
Acute patellar tendon tears are most commonly caused by trauma to the infrapatellar region (e.g., sliding into home plate, chronic tendon degeneration) due to sudden contraction of the quadriceps. Physical examination typically reveals anterior knee pain, effusion, and an inability to extend the knee and keep the leg straight when flexing the hip. X-rays of the knee will show a high-riding patella because of unopposed quadriceps tendon force. Partial patellar tendon tear can usually be managed conservatively with immobilization and physical therapy, while complete patellar tendon tears are managed surgically with end-to-end suturing of the patellar tendon.

In contrast, a low-riding patella indicates a tear of the quadriceps tendon. (See “Distinguishing features of knee tendon injuries” table.)

images.title: Patella alta from patellar tendon rupture
images.description: X-ray knee (lateral view)The patella is abnormally high-riding (patella alta; normal position illustrated by outline). Although no fracture fragment is visible, a small defect at the patellar apex (green overlay) raises question of a prior avulsion fracture.Patellar tendon rupture can result from trauma or systemic illness. A traumatic rupture usually occurs at either the patellar or tibial insertion site and may be accompanied by an avulsion fracture. A systemic illness usually results in a midtendon tear.F: femur; T: tibia

answers.explanation_why: Traumatic patellar subluxations typically manifest with anterior knee pain, swelling, and a restricted range of motion with the knee usually held in fixed flexion. However, x-rays of the knee almost always show a lateral displacement of the patella, rather than a high-riding patella.

images.title: Lateral patellar dislocation
images.description: X-ray left knee (AP view)The patella (green overlay) is displaced laterally. It is normally located anterior to a groove between the femoral condyles (the patellofemoral groove; indicated by red overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Meniscus tears most commonly manifest with knee pain and swelling, and restricted knee extension. However, knee pain is usually located at the medial or lateral joint line rather than the anterior part of the knee. Additionally, physical examination would most likely reveal clicking sounds or a locking sensation with knee extension; weight-bearing is usually not limited. Moreover, x-rays of the knee are typically unremarkable in meniscus tears.

images.title: Horizontal tear of the medial meniscus
images.description: MRI knee (upper image: T1-weighted, coronal plane; lower image: T1-weighted, sagittal plane)There is horizontal linear intermediate signal (white outline), parallel to the tibial plateau, within the posterior horn of the medial meniscus (green overlay).This is consistent with a horizontal meniscal tear.Red overlay: anterior horn of the medial meniscus

answers.explanation_why: Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tears are most commonly caused by a twisting mechanism or direct blow to the knee and typically manifest with sudden-onset knee pain and swelling. However, patients with ACL tears typically report a popping sound upon injury and a positive Lachman test on physical examination, rather than an inability to extend the knee. X-rays of the knee are often normal but may show a deep lateral sulcus sign or tibial eminence avulsion fracture.

images.title: Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament
images.description: MRI of the knee (T1-weighted, coronal view)Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament.

answers.explanation_why: Quadriceps tendon tears are usually acute, caused by a sudden and strong contraction of the quadriceps muscles, and manifest with knee pain, effusion, and inability to extend the knee. However, the quadriceps tendon attaches to the superior aspect of the patella, so x-rays of the knee typically show a low-riding patella and a lack of quadriceps shadow rather than a high-riding patella.

images.title: Quadriceps tendon tear
images.description:
Left: MRI knee (PD weighted (Fat Sat); sagittal plane)
Right: X-ray knee (lateral view)MRI shows a quadriceps tendon tear (red overlay) accompanied by extensive hyperintense fluid (indicated by green arrowheads), including a joint effusion. The radiograph shows some soft tissue thickening in the suprapatellar region (green overlay) and a small calcification (yellow arrowhead).

question_text: A 63-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of 4-day history of fatigue and right knee pain. He spent 6 hours the day before the symptoms began laying floor tiles in his new home. He has hypertension and monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance. His medications are lisinopril and a daily multivitamin. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. He works as a carpenter. He is 180 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 74 kg (163 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m^2. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 141/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a tender, warm, erythematous right knee. There is a palpable prepatellar swelling. The end range of active right knee extension is limited by pain; passive range of motion is normal. Examination of the left leg shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 63-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of 4-day history of fatigue and right knee pain. He spent 6 hours the day before the symptoms began laying floor tiles in his new home. He has hypertension and monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance. His medications are lisinopril and a daily multivitamin. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. He works as a carpenter. He is 180 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 74 kg (163 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 141/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a tender, warm, erythematous right knee. There is a palpable prepatellar swelling. The end range of active right knee extension is limited by pain; passive range of motion is normal. Examination of the left leg shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Acute anterior knee pain, erythema, warmth, and localized swelling anterior to the patella after prolonged activity on the knees, which can result in superficial skin abrasions, strongly suggest prepatellar bursitis.
learning_objective: Recognize prepatellar bursitis, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: Intraarticular glucocorticoid injection can be used to treat chronic osteoarthritis, which can manifest with knee pain and swelling in an older individual. However, the onset of pain in osteoarthritis is insidious, rather than acute. Moreover, erythema, fever, tachycardia, and fatigue suggest an infection, which is a contraindication for intraarticular glucocorticoid injections. This patient's prepatellar swelling and normal range of motion indicate that the source of his symptoms is located outside of the joint.

Oral dicloxacillin therapy is indicated for septic bursitis that is caused by an organism susceptible to dicloxacillin, such as Staphylococcus aureus, which is the most common causal organism. Patients with septic bursitis are initially treated with empiric antibiotic therapy until the causative pathogen is identified. In addition, a different step in management is indicated before treatment is begun.

Diagnostic bursal fluid aspiration is indicated in all patients who have bursitis in a superficial bursa. The aspirated fluid should be analyzed for infection via Gram stain, bacterial culture, and a white blood cell count with differential, as well as for crystal arthropathies via examination under a polarizing microscope. An immunocompromised state (e.g., monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance) is a risk factor for developing septic bursitis, which can manifest acutely with local findings as well as fatigue, myalgia, and/or fever. Empiric antibiotics against staphylococci and streptococci should be initiated in this patient after fluid aspiration and adjusted according to bursal fluid culture results. Imaging is usually unnecessary unless bone involvement is suspected. Complications of bursal fluid aspiration include spread of infection to the adjacent bursa or joint.

Rest, ice, compression, and elevation (RICE) is indicated for the initial treatment of noninfectious bursitis. This patient, however, has additional signs of infection, such as fever, fatigue, and tachycardia. Therefore, he requires another form of management before conservative therapy is initiated.

Arthroscopy of the knee may be indicated in patients with suspected intraarticular pathology (e.g., meniscal injuries). However, this patient has a prepatellar swelling, which indicates an extraarticular pathology. In addition, this patient has a normal range of motion in his knee joint, making an intraarticular pathology unlikely.

question_text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of left ankle pain and swelling for the last 4 days after she missed a step and fell down the stairs. She has been able to move around slowly but is worried because the pain has not subsided despite taking acetaminophen. She is otherwise healthy. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 74 kg (163 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows moderate swelling of the left ankle and tenderness along the anterior edge of the lateral malleolus. Range of motion at the left ankle joint is limited due to pain. Left dorsalis pedis pulse is 2+. She walks without a limp. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of left ankle pain and swelling for the last 4 days after she missed a step and fell down the stairs. She has been able to move around slowly but is worried because the pain has not subsided despite taking acetaminophen. She is otherwise healthy. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 74 kg (163 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows moderate swelling of the left ankle and tenderness along the anterior edge of the lateral malleolus. Range of motion at the left ankle joint is limited due to pain. Left dorsalis pedis pulse is 2+. She walks without a limp. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The combination of ankle pain, swelling, limited range of motion, tenderness along the anterior lateral malleolus, and preserved ability to bear weight after a traumatic event suggests a lateral ankle sprain.
learning_objective: Recognize a lateral ankle sprain, and choose conservative treatment measures.

answers.content: Protected weight bearing, cooling, and compression
answers.explanation_why:
Ankle sprains are most commonly caused by injury of the anterior talofibular ligament due to excessive inversion of the foot. Conservative treatment for acute ankle sprains consists of protection, optimal loading, ice, compression, and elevation (POLICE principle), along with NSAIDs for analgesia. Immediately after the injury, patients should undergo a brief period of relative rest followed by mobilization exercises within a pain-free range and protected weight bearing. Conservative treatment is indicated in patients with normal x-rays and in those who do not require imaging according to the Ottawa ankle rules. Accordingly, because this patient is able to bear weight on the ankle and does not have point tenderness at the posterior edge or tip of the lateral or medial malleolus, x-rays are not required.

If ankle instability or severe pain is present, a cast boot or short leg cast can be used for a few days. Surgery may be indicated if there is ligament rupture, especially in patients who are likely to experience continuous stress on the ankle joint, such as professional athletes.

Surgical reconstruction of ankle ligaments may be considered in patients with chronic ankle instability, as evidenced by recurrent ankle sprains, or in patients with a complete tear of the ligament who are likely to experience continuous stress at the ankle joint (e.g., professional athletes). This patient does not experience recurrent ankle sprains and has no signs of a ruptured ligament (e.g., ecchymosis, ankle instability, inability to bear weight).

An MRI of the ankle is used to assess ankle sprains that do not respond to conservative therapy (i.e., pain persists after 6–8 weeks). This patient is only 4 days post-injury and in the acute setting, an MRI has no advantage over x-rays.

answers.content: Leg cast to immobilize the ankle
answers.explanation_why: A leg cast is used to immobilize the ankle in patients who have an ankle fracture or an ankle sprain with severe pain and ankle instability (grade III sprain). Usually, these patients cannot bear weight on the affected ankle. This patient, however, has been able to bear weight for the past 4 days. Moreover, an ankle fracture or grade III sprain manifests with severe pain, swelling, ecchymosis, ankle instability, and tenderness along the malleolus, whereas this patient only has moderate swelling, no ecchymosis, and a stable ankle joint.

The Ottawa ankle rules are used to determine whether a patient with foot pain requires an x-ray. Imaging is indicated for patients who are unable to bear weight on the affected foot or have tenderness at the posterior edge of the medial or lateral malleolus. As this patient is able to bear weight and pain is localized to the anterior edge of the malleolus, x-rays are not indicated.

question_text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of worsening dull left shoulder pain. The pain has caused her to wake up most nights. She regularly plays volleyball with her daughter but she says that her shoulder feels “very stiff” now and changing clothes or fastening her bra has become increasingly difficult over the past 6 months. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. Two years ago, she had a type 1 acromioclavicular joint injury treated with a sling. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a markedly decreased active and passive range of motion in her left shoulder due to pain; muscle strength is 4/5 in her left shoulder. Neurologic examination shows no other focal findings. X-rays of the left shoulder show no abnormalities. In addition to prescribing analgesics, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of worsening dull left shoulder pain. The pain has caused her to wake up most nights. She regularly plays volleyball with her daughter but she says that her shoulder feels “very stiff” now and changing clothes or fastening her bra has become increasingly difficult over the past 6 months. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. Two years ago, she had a type 1 acromioclavicular joint injury treated with a sling. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a markedly decreased active and passive range of motion in her left shoulder due to pain; muscle strength is 4/5 in her left shoulder. Neurologic examination shows no other focal findings. X-rays of the left shoulder show no abnormalities. In addition to prescribing analgesics, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: A history of a shoulder injury in a patient with progressive unilateral shoulder pain and stiffness who is otherwise physically active suggests adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder).
learning_objective: Recognize adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder), and choose the most appropriate initial treatment.

answers.explanation_why: The initial treatment of adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder) should consist of conservative measures such as movement restriction (e.g., overhead movements), NSAIDs, and physical therapy for shoulder range-of-motion exercises. Physical therapy should aim to strengthen and gently stretch the shoulder while avoiding aggressive exercises that would aggravate the capsular synovitis and cause undue discomfort. Patients with previous shoulder injuries and/or surgeries, diabetes mellitus, and other systemic diseases (e.g., stroke, thyroid, autoimmune) are at increased risk of developing adhesive capsulitis.

images.title: Frozen shoulder
images.description:
Frontal cross-section of the shoulder and the three stages of frozen shoulderStage 1 (freezing stage): minimal synovitis with pain and limitation of motion
Stage 2 (frozen stage): proliferative synovitis with contraction of the capsule and adhesion of the axillary recess
Stage 3 (thawing stage): contracted capsule following the end of inflammation

answers.explanation_why: A short course of oral corticosteroids can help to improve mobility and reduce pain in patients with adhesive capsulitis. However, this benefit does not extend beyond a few weeks and is typically not recommended due to the systemic side effects of corticosteroids (e.g., hypertension, hyperglycemia, weight gain, peptic ulcers, myopathy, psychosis). Instead, conservative measures should be trialed first. In patients who do not respond to conservative measures, intraarticular glucocorticoid injections, which have more localized effects, can be considered instead of oral steroids.

Surgical treatment, such as the arthroscopic release of the glenohumeral joint capsule, can be used to treat adhesive capsulitis. However, surgical interventions should be reserved for patients who have not responded to conservative measures (e.g., physical therapy, NSAIDs, shoulder injections). Conservative measures should be exhausted in this patient before surgery is considered.

answers.content: Recommend shoulder immobilization with a sling
answers.explanation_why: Immobilization of the shoulder should be considered after an injury to the acromioclavicular joint, which typically occurs after trauma and can manifest with swelling and/or bruising. This patient's normal x-ray and symptoms indicate adhesive capsulitis, which can worsen with immobilization.

MRI of the shoulder can be used to assess soft tissue injuries (e.g., rotator cuff tendons, bursa, shoulder ligaments) and can show thickening of the glenohumeral capsule in patients with adhesive capsulitis. However, adhesive capsulitis is typically diagnosed based on patient history and physical examination; MRI is not recommended unless the patient has evidence of another pathology. This patient's adhesive capsulitis can be diagnosed clinically and treatment should be started.

question_text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of swelling and burning pain in her left lower leg for the past 2 weeks. She fractured her left femur 2 months ago in a skiing accident and underwent intramedullary nailing. Her initial postoperative course was uncomplicated. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. She drinks one glass of wine daily and does not smoke. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows 1+ pitting edema of the left ankle; the patient experiences a painful sensation on light touch. There is decreased skin temperature in the left lower leg. Muscle strength is 5/5 for dorsiflexion of the left foot. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Dorsalis pedis pulses are 2+ bilaterally. There is a well-healed scar on the left lateral thigh. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum D-dimer level is 230 ng/mL (N ≤ 250 ng/mL). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of swelling and burning pain in her left lower leg for the past 2 weeks. She fractured her left femur 2 months ago in a skiing accident and underwent intramedullary nailing. Her initial postoperative course was uncomplicated. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. She drinks one glass of wine daily and does not smoke. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows 1+ pitting edema of the left ankle; the patient experiences a painful sensation on light touch. There is decreased skin temperature in the left lower leg. Muscle strength is 5/5 for dorsiflexion of the left foot. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Dorsalis pedis pulses are 2+ bilaterally. There is a well-healed scar on the left lateral thigh. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum D-dimer level is 230 ng/mL (N ≤ 250 ng/mL). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Leg pain in combination with edema and sensory and vasomotor symptoms following a femur fracture is consistent with complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS).
learning_objective: Recognize complex regional pain syndrome, and choose the most appropriate initial therapy.

answers.explanation_why: Cold avoidance and nifedipine therapy are used in the management of Raynaud phenomenon, which typically manifests with pain and/or paresthesias in the extremities. However, pain due to Raynaud phenomenon is episodic and transient and is associated with triggers (e.g., cold air). Moreover, limb edema is not a feature of this condition. Finally, Raynaud phenomenon most commonly affects the fingers and toes. This patient's symptoms are more consistent with CRPS, which requires a different type of management.

images.title: Raynaud's phenomenon
images.description: White discoloration of 3rd–5th digits of the left hand, and 2nd–5th digits of the right hand, extending from the fingertip to the proximal interphalangeal joints (ischemic phase).

answers.explanation_why: In patients with diabetes mellitus, hemoglobin A_1c is measured to determine long-term glycemic control. Poor glycemic control is a risk factor for developing diabetic neuropathy, which can manifest with dysesthesia in the affected extremities. However, this patient does not have progressive loss of sensation in the affected limb, which is typical in diabetic neuropathy. Moreover, this condition typically causes distal symmetric polyneuropathy. This patient's current symptoms are consistent with CRPS, which requires a different type of management.

Lower extremity venous ultrasound is used in diagnosing deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in patients with a moderate or high Wells score. For up to 2–3 months after surgery, patients are at risk for DVT, which can manifest with unilateral leg pain and swelling. However, DVT typically manifests with a dull aching pain rather than burning pain and causes warmth in the affected limb rather than decreased temperature. This condition does not cause allodynia. Moreover, this patient has a Wells score of 0 and a normal D-dimer level, both of which rule out DVT. This patient's symptoms are consistent with complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS), which requires a different type of management.

answers.content: Digital subtraction angiography of the lower extremities
answers.explanation_why: Digital subtraction angiography of the lower extremities is used to diagnose peripheral arterial disease (PAD), which can manifest with pain and decreased skin temperature in the affected extremity. However, PAD does not cause allodynia or limb swelling and manifests with decreased peripheral pulses (e.g., dorsalis pedis). This patient's symptoms are consistent with CRPS, which requires a different type of management.

The pathogenesis of CRPS is unknown but is often linked to an inciting event, most commonly trauma, and symptoms usually develop within 4–6 weeks of the event. Pathomechanisms thought to be involved include abnormal local inflammatory response, dysfunctional pain perception, and sympathetic overactivity. Physical and occupational therapy is the recommended first-line therapy for CRPS. Therapy focuses on ensuring daily function and motion of the affected limb, decreasing pain, and improving the patient's quality of life. Commonly used strategies include desensitization and relaxation techniques, gait retraining, functional activities, and edema control strategies. Patients with CRPS may also require medical therapy for pain management (e.g., oral corticosteroids).

images.title: Complex regional pain syndrome of the right foot (CRPS)
images.description:
The right one appears erythematous and swollen by edema. The swelling extends up to the calf and makes the skin look tightened and gleaming.
Moreover, the ankle is in a dystonic position (flexion and slight supination).This finding is typical of Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS). A unilateral swelling like this could also be from a different origin, e.g., traumatic injury.

question_text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of worsening pain in her right knee. The pain is exacerbated when she climbs the stairs to her apartment on the 4^th floor. Treatment with ibuprofen has provided moderate pain relief. Medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin. She has smoked 4–5 cigarettes daily for 20 years. She is 165 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right knee shows tenderness to palpation on the right upper medial tibia; there is no swelling. Knee extension with passive external rotation and valgus stress does not cause pain. There is no joint instability when gentle valgus stress is applied across the knee. Examination of the left knee shows no abnormalities. X-ray of the right knee shows osteophyte formation and narrowing of the joint space. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 52-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of worsening pain in her right knee. The pain is exacerbated when she climbs the stairs to her apartment on the 4th floor. Treatment with ibuprofen has provided moderate pain relief. Medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin. She has smoked 4–5 cigarettes daily for 20 years. She is 165 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right knee shows tenderness to palpation on the right upper medial tibia; there is no swelling. Knee extension with passive external rotation and valgus stress does not cause pain. There is no joint instability when gentle valgus stress is applied across the knee. Examination of the left knee shows no abnormalities. X-ray of the right knee shows osteophyte formation and narrowing of the joint space. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Pain on the medial aspect of the knee and upper medial tibia without signs of inflammation is characteristic of pes anserinus pain syndrome (PAPS). Risk factors for this condition include obesity, osteoarthritis, and type 2 diabetes mellitus.
learning_objective: Recognize pes anserinus pain syndrome, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Bursal fluid aspiration is indicated in patients with acute bursitis to rule out infection or gout. However, acute bursitis typically also manifests with local signs of inflammation (local joint swelling, erythema, warmth), which are not seen here.

Quadriceps-strengthening exercises are recommended for the management of PAPS to reduce pain and improve knee stability by strengthening the muscles that act on the knee. Patients with PAPS should avoid heavy impact activities and be prescribed analgesia as needed. Weight loss is recommended in patients with obesity. Patients with refractory symptoms may benefit from steroid injections.

Glucocorticoid injections can be used in the management of PAPS and osteoarthritis (OA), both conditions which this patient has. However, glucocorticoid injections are only indicated if the patient has persistent symptoms that do not resolve after initial therapy. A different step in management is more appropriate at this time.

MRI of the knee can be used in the evaluation of PAPS and osteoarthritis (OA), both conditions which this patient has. However, MRI is only indicated in patients with PAPS who present with local inflammation and/or induration to exclude alternative diagnoses (e.g., tumors, meniscal tears, osteonecrosis). Moreover, the use of MRI to evaluate OA is not routine and should only be considered in specific cases (e.g., atypical symptoms, young adults and children, knee locking).
A soft knee brace can be used to reduce instability in patients with PAPS. However, crutches are not recommended for this patient because there is no contraindication for weightbearing in PAPS.

question_text: A 78-year-old woman is evaluated in the rehabilitation facility of a hospital 2 weeks after admission for an ischemic stroke that resulted in right hemiparesis. She has been recovering well. She can walk with the aid of a walker, has no speech impairment, and tolerates a regular diet. Medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Medications are metformin, lisinopril, simvastatin, and daily aspirin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Cranial nerves are intact. Muscle strength in the extremities is 5/5 on the left and 3/5 on the right. Sensation is intact bilaterally. Standardized assessment of cognitive function shows mild impairment. The patient says that she is tired of being in the hospital. She lives alone in a small apartment on the ground floor with no stairs. The patient's daughter agrees to take care of her mother but mentions that she cannot afford to take any more time off work. The daughter works part-time as a kindergarten teacher. Which of the following is the most appropriate action to ensure the patient's well-being?
content_preview: A 78-year-old woman is evaluated in the rehabilitation facility of a hospital 2 weeks after admission for an ischemic stroke that resulted in right hemiparesis. She has been recovering well. She can walk with the aid of a walker, has no speech impairment, and tolerates a regular diet. Medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Medications are metformin, lisinopril, simvastatin, and daily aspirin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Cranial nerves are intact. Muscle strength in the extremities is 5/5 on the left and 3/5 on the right. Sensation is intact bilaterally. Standardized assessment of cognitive function shows mild impairment. The patient says that she is tired of being in the hospital. She lives alone in a small apartment on the ground floor with no stairs. The patient's daughter agrees to take care of her mother but mentions that she cannot afford to take any more time off work. The daughter works part-time as a kindergarten teacher. Which of the following is the most appropriate action to ensure the patient's well-being?
hint: Discharge planning is the process of developing an individualized plan to ensure the safe transition of a patient from the hospital to another care setting (e.g., home health care, skilled nursing facility).
learning_objective: Recognize the role of a social worker in multidisciplinary discharge planning.

answers.explanation_why: Prolonged hospitalization can raise certain risks (e.g., hospital-acquired infections) in older patients and disrupt others' access to care. In addition, physicians should be mindful of the impact on health care resources (e.g., staffing, health care costs). This patient is medically stable and should not be kept at the hospital any longer than necessary.

answers.content: Transfer responsibility for discharge planning to the patient's daughter
answers.explanation_why: The physician should involve the patient's family and future caregivers in discharge planning and identify who will be primarily responsible for understanding the discharge instructions. However, physicians, together with other health care personnel, are obligated to ensure safe discharge planning, and this responsibility cannot be transferred to a family member.

answers.content: Discharge the patient to an assisted living facility
answers.explanation_why: An inpatient program (e.g., assisted living facilities) may be appropriate for patients who require skilled care services. However, assuming that a safe discharge can be ensured, the patient's needs and preferences should also be considered during discharge planning. Therefore, discharge to an assisted living facility without prior discussion with the patient and their family is inappropriate.

answers.content: Discuss a plan for regular outpatient visits with the patient
answers.explanation_why: Physicians should involve patients in decision-making processes (e.g., discharge planning) and respect their individual preferences. This patient with a history of stroke, hemiparesis, and mild cognitive impairment requires skilled medical services (e.g., physical therapy, skilled nursing care) and is unlikely to be able to travel to outpatient therapy. Therefore, a plan that only consists of regular outpatient visits is not feasible.

answers.content: Involve a social worker in discharge planning
answers.explanation_why:
The physician is responsible for assessing whether to involve a multidisciplinary team of discharge planners (usually social workers and/or nurses). Discharge planners can be especially helpful for patients who are at high risk for adverse events after discharge and require ongoing skilled care. Discharge planning should be initiated as early as possible and includes a psychosocial assessment, discharge counseling, medication reconciliation, planning of follow-up visits, and coordination of services. The patient, their family, and future caregivers should be involved to establish a plan that meets the patient's medical needs and personal preferences. Effective discharge planning can increase patient satisfaction, reduce the duration of hospitalization, and decrease readmission rates.

Home health care should be considered for patients who live at home and require complex ongoing care but are unable to travel. This form of rehabilitation reduces costs while avoiding the risks associated with prolonged hospitalization (e.g., nosocomial infections).
